page.title: 13Local History, Gwyddelwern.
page.content: Some time before{600 AD}a group of {Irish}immigrants left the stone hill-top camp on Caer Druwyn, moved into the valley and settled on the marshy ground which was thenceforth known as the swamp of the Irish {(Goddelwern) - Gwyddelwern. St Bueno found them there and persuaded the king of the district to give him land on which to build the first church of wattle and daub with a thatched roof. Like him the Irish were Celtic Christians. The first recorded Vicar was appointed in 1535 and three years later the first stone church was built. Of the medieaval stained glass which filled its windows only two small fragments remain. In the{Eighteenth Century,}the village itself had four houses and two taverns, but the workers from nearby estates filled the church on Sundays.
